151. Campbell, Elsie S.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Elsie (Lester) Campbell
Address: Box 222, Biggar, Sask. Pioneered at 9 mi. E. of Saskatoon
Birthplace: England in 1905.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1905 in tent - 3 of us.
Where did you set up housekeeping? 9 mi. E. of Saskatoon.
Where had you been living before that? England.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6. What there was.
How far was it to your nearest store? 9 mi.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Bicycle when necessary.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, potatoes, canned milk, flour, salt, sugar, tea, oats.
Got horses in 1907, then took load 8 days to town for groceries. Currie's store & J.J. Carman.

In what quantities did you buy it? 140.

Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, rice.
Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?

How did you grind it?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout)

We had no water in 9 yrs. the we dug 3 wells & drilled one. Had to haul 1 to 2 mi. within from neighbors well or from slough of barrels. I used to ride full gallop a mile in winter to water them.

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Mother used to melt snow for the house, no storm windows, ice was an inch deep on windows.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, cistern, dugout)

We had no water in 9 this the we dug 7 wells

How far was this water from your home? (miles, barrel, tank) We had to walk through the woods to get to it

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) We had to carry it ourselves

Bezarding water supply, mention any chances which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

First started housekeeping in 1920. Will green pick up the fuel. She bought wood in the house, no storm pick up the fuel. She was an independent.

My mother gathered dry wood from burned out bluffs near home. The rest was hauled 2-1/2 miles from bluffs. I drove team home. Mother helped me unload & went back, having to walk behind to keep from freezing to where father & brother later died from heart disease - had got another load ready.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Self & 2 brothers in tent + father when not away working first summer. Built sod house, frame poles blew down once. Poles & hay on roof, lined inside with canvas. Mother & 3 others spent one or two winters in it, then built house & lumber.

First Christmas self 9, sister 12, bros. 14, 16, Dad.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Spent winter 1906/7 in Saskatoon Ave. C. (In the fall had been in a tent there + my father & brother had to go to hospital with typhoid fever.) That winter father was night watchman on the beginning of the old traffic bridge. He fell in & got a wetting one night. My brother worked at a butcher's. I went to the old stone school on 3rd Ave. So, my mother & youngest bro. + sister are school.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Can't remember anything we had to eat, but in 1906/7 had learnt to catch chickens at back of house. We could have eaten the muskrats which we caught & dressed the skins & sold them for only eight cents each '08 - beautiful skins. Only brothers sampled the muskrat for eating just for fun.

To homestead + sod house on top of load of lumber. Mother got rheumatic fever for 6 wks + cd. Have died. No Doctor, no medicine, + only pole + hay beds so wonder she hated Canada. She died of heart disease in 1931. She was brought up as an artist & cd. only do bookkeeping.
I wish you a happy new year, dear friend.

In the fall of 1906, my father and I went to hospital with typhoid fever. That winter, father was very weak. He fell ill again in December. We had to go to hospital again. My mother worked at the hospital for only eight cents each day. She was very kind to us.

Mother got rheumatic fever for six weeks and died. No wonder she looked so pale and weakly. She died of heart disease in 1931. She was brought up as an artist and only did bookkeeping.
20. Question not outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. We made our own bread and biscuits only in store. In the first year, my sister and I let the bread rise out in the sun for five minutes and then dry the dishes. Brother had worked at a bakery in England, so made the bread.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). Moved to Sutherland in 1914.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

First summer actually tried fishing in the slough, too bad there weren't some there. Money was the worst shortage. Mother sent a list to town after '68 "as long as her arm" but didn't get them all. Had plenty to eat after we got a crop. Mother's sisters in England sent her dresses - beautiful ones. I learned to make my own before I left home. I worked for my board while home. Finished school in town. (Gr. 8 1913)

Won P.A.D.E. essay contest for the whole of Gr. 8 1917 Saskatoon. My sister was in the next year & youngest here. The next year he went south to school.
21. How did you benefit by purchasing goods and supplies from local stores? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and supplies in other towns during pioneer days in Southern Canada.

Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, etc.

If possible, include prices paid at the time.

The following year actually tried farming in a field to earn a living. We had plenty to eat but didn't get along well. Mother worked in England and sent her earnings - beautiful ones.

I planned to make my own living while I finished school in town. (8/1913)

My sister moved to the west coast for work. She hasn't heard from me since.
